info: Look up tonight and see a whole bunch of planets. Just after sunset, looking west, planets Venus, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars will all be simultaneously visible.
This line of stars is real. A little too faint to see with the unaided eye, Kemble’s Cascade of stars inspires awe when seen with binoculars.

description: CG4: The Globule and the Galaxy
info: Can a gas cloud eat a galaxy? It's not even close. The 'claw' of this odd looking 'creature' in the featured photo is a gas cloud known as a cometary globule.

description: Space Stations in Low Earth Orbit
info: Two space stations already illuminated by sunlight in low Earth orbit crossed this dark predawn sky.
Comet ZTF may become visible to the unaided eye.
Stars are forming in the gigantic dust pillar called the Cone Nebula.
The scene may look like a fantasy, but it's really Iceland.
This cosmic expanse of dust, gas, and stars covers some 6 degrees on the sky in the heroic constellation Perseus.
The most massive young star cluster in the Small Magellanic Cloud is NGC 346, embedded in our small satellite galaxy's largest star forming region some 210,000 light-years distant.
Lynds' Dark Nebula (LDN) 1622 appears against a faint background of glowing hydrogen gas only visible in long telescopic exposures of the region

description: The Colliding Spiral Galaxies of Arp 274
info: Two galaxies are squaring off in Virgo
This is the mess that is left when a star explodes.
Why are there oxygen-emitting arcs near the direction of the Andromeda galaxy? No one is sure.
MACS0647: Gravitational Lensing of the Early Universe
A broad expanse of glowing gas and dust presents a bird-like visage
The two dominant galaxies near center are far far away, 12 million light-years distant toward the northern constellation of the Great Bear.
